Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Systemic Opioid Analgesics in Neonates Post-Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive opioids or comparators.

Participants.evidence: preterm and term infants up to 46 weeks postmenstrual age with postoperative pain

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive opioids or comparators.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the benefits and harms of systemic opioid analgesics compared to placebo, non-pharmacological interventions, different opioids, or other drugs.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was pain, assessed using validated methods during initial hospitalisation.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Four RCTs with 331 infants were included.

Result_Outcome.evidence: For tramadol vs. placebo, RR for mortality was 0.32 (95% CI 0.01 to 7.70). For fentanyl vs. tramadol, RR was 0.99 (95% CI 0.59 to 1.64). For morphine vs. paracetamol, MD in pain scores was 0.10 (95% CI -0.85 to 1.05).
